Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the alleged secret document by stating that it is "unbelievable but true" and that it exposes an "evil" plot.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide any credible evidence or sources to support the existence of the secret document or its connection to the Ghanaian President.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the voice recording accurately quotes a Rockefeller Foundation article, without providing any proof of its authenticity.
Exist alternative explanation: The Information Minister of Ghana confirms that the audio recording was not made by the president, suggesting an alternative explanation for its origin.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the voice in the audio recording does not match the voice of the Ghanaian President, as confirmed by the Information Minister.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on conspiracy theories and unsupported claims about the creation and release of COVID-19 as part of a "New World Order" agenda.
